chapterTitle: Behavioral Finance: Implications For Financial Management

columns.text: Here, we will define the important and relevant terms regarding the biases in judging a certain project or company.

**2a**. **Overconfidence** occurs when you think that a certain decision outweighs the odds. This happens when you overestimate that the pros heavily outweigh the cons. 

This can be costly especially if you pick risky investments since you think that these have high upside without actually knowing much about it. This creates the tendency to overtrade or to buy at higher prices.

**2b**. Optimism is a person's ability to see and expect a good outcome out of something. This means that **overoptimism** can create an illusion wherein a certain event has a very high chance of having a good outcome while discounting the chance of it having negative outcomes.

This can be costly especially when investing in up and coming stocks or in start ups. Overoptimistic people can disregard factors that can indicate that the project is bound to fail or is bound to generate losses because they are highly optimistic that the stock or start-up can bounce back easily.

**2c.** It is natural to have biases especially since we all have our own opinion. However, **confirmation bias** refers to a person's ability to downplay or disregard information that is not similar to their insights. This happens when a person is already set on something so when they are presented with the pros and cons, they will only often take note of the pros. 

Confirmation bias can be costly since a person can have an affinity to a certain product from a company so that person chooses to invest in it despite many indicators telling otherwise. This happens because that person only listens to information that supports their stance on the product or company. So even if the disadvantages outweigh the pros, they will still invest in the product due to their bias.
